revision.text:
{{wiktionary}} An '''adulterant''' is a [[pejorative]] term for a substance found within other substances such as [[food]], [[fuel]]s or chemicals even though it is not allowed for legal or other reasons. It will not normally be present in any specification or declared contents of the substance, and may not be legally allowed. The addition of adulterants is called '''adulteration'''. The most common reason for adulteration is the use by manufacturers of undeclared materials that are cheaper than the correct and declared ones. The adulterants may be harmful, or reduce the potency of the product, or they may be harmless. The term "[[contamination]]" is usually used for the inclusion of unwanted substances due to accident or negligence rather than intent, and also for the introduction of unwanted substances after the product has been made. Adulteration therefore implies that the adulterant was introduced deliberately in the initial manufacturing process, or sometimes that it was present in the raw materials and should have been removed, but was not. An adulterant is distinct from, for example, permitted [[food additive]]s. There can be a fine line between adulterant and additive; [[chicory]] may be added to [[coffee]] to reduce the cost or achieve a desired flavour—this is adulteration if not declared, but may be stated on the label. [[Chalk]] was often added to [[bread flour]]; this reduces the cost and increases whiteness, but the [[calcium]] actually confers health benefits, and in modern bread a little chalk may be included as an additive for this reason. In wartime adulterants have been added to make foodstuffs "go further" and prevent shortages. The German word ''[[ersatz]]'' is widely recognised from such practices during [[World War II]]. Such adulteration was sometimes deliberately hidden from the population to prevent loss of morale and propaganda reasons. Some goods considered luxurious in the [[Communist Bloc]] such as coffee were adulterated to make them affordable to the general population. Adulterants added to reduce the amount of expensive product in [[illicit drugs]] are called [[cutting agent]]s. Deliberate addition of toxic adulterants to food or other products for human consumption is [[poison]]ing. ==In food and beverages== Past and present examples of adulteration, some dangerous, include: * Roasted [[chicory]] roots used as an adulterant for [[coffee]] * [[Diethylene glycol]], used dangerously by some winemakers in [[sweet wine]]s * [[Apple]] jellies (jams), as substitutes for more expensive fruit [[Fruit preserves|jellies]], with added colorant and sometimes even specks of wood that simulate raspberry or strawberry seeds * [[Water]], for diluting [[milk]] and [[alcoholic beverage]]s * [[Cutting agent]]s used to adulterate (or "cut") illicit drugs—for example, [[shoe polish]] in [[hashish]], [[amphetamine]]s in [[Ecstasy (drug)|ecstasy]], [[lactose]] in [[cocaine]] * [[Urea]], [[melamine]] and other nonprotein [[nitrogen]] sources, added to [[protein]] products to inflate crude protein content measurements{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/food/2007-04-25-melamine-usat_N.htm |first=Elizabeth |last=Weise |title=Food tests promise tough task for FDA |publisher=[[USA Today]] |date=April 24, 2007 |accessdate=2007-04-29}} * [[High fructose corn syrup]] or [[cane sugar]], used to adulterate [[honey]] * Water or [[brine]] injected into chicken, pork, or other meats to increase their weight{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/09/dining/09well.html?ex=1159243200&en=17c3332c2ab7cd8d&ei=5070 | work=The New York Times | first=Marian | last=Burros | title=The Customer Wants a Juicy Steak? Just Add Water | date=2006-08-09}} * [[Red ochre]]–soaked [[brown bread]] to give the appearance of [[beef sausage]] for [[sausage roll]] filling.The Times, ''Police'', 5 February 1894; pg. 14 ==History== Historically, the use of adulterants has been common; sometimes dangerous substances have been used. In the [[United Kingdom]] up to the [[Victorian era]], adulterants were common; for example, [[cheese]]s were sometimes colored with [[lead]]. Similar adulteration issues were seen in industry in the [[United States]], during the 19th century. There is dispute over whether these practices declined primarily due to government regulation or to increased public awareness and concern over the practices. In the early 21st century, cases of dangerous adulteration occurred in the [[People's Republic of China]]. In some African countries, it is not uncommon for thieves to break electric [[transformer]]s to steal [[transformer oil]], which is then sold to the operators of roadside [[food stall]]s to be used for [[deep frying]]. When used for frying, it is reported that transformer oil lasts much longer than regular [[cooking oil]]. The downside of this misuse of the transformer oil is the threat to the health of the consumers, due to the presence of [[PCBs]].[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/12/thieves-fry-kenya-power-grid-fast-food-2014122884728785480.html Thieves fry Kenya's power grid for fast food], Al Jazeera, 2014-12-28 Adulterant use was first investigated in [[1820#Events|1820]] by the German chemist [[Frederick Accum]], who identified many toxic metal colorings in food and drink. His work antagonized food suppliers, and he was ultimately discredited by a scandal over his alleged mutilation of books of the [[Royal Institution]] library. The physician [[Arthur Hill Hassall]] conducted extensive studies in the early 1850s, which were published in ''[[The Lancet]]'' and led to the 1860 Food Adulteration Act and other legislation.{{cite magazine |last= Coley |first= Noel |date= 1 March 2005 |title= The fight against food adulteration |url= https://eic.rsc.org/feature/the-fight-against-food-adulteration/2020253.article |magazine= [[Education in Chemistry]] |volume= 42 |issue= 2 |pages= 46–49 |publisher= [[Royal Society of Chemistry]] |access-date= 19 June 2018 }} [[John Postgate (food safety campaigner)|John Postgate]] led a further campaign, leading to another Act of 1875, which forms the basis of the modern legislation and a system of [[public analyst]]s who test for adulteration. At the turn of the 20th century, industrialization in the United States led to a rise in adulteration which inspired some protest. Accounts of adulteration led the [[New York Evening Post|New York ''Evening Post'']] to parody:
Mary had a little lamb, And when she saw it sicken, She shipped it off to Packingtown, And now it's labeled chicken.Jeffrey M. Pilcher, ''Food in World History'' New York: [[Routledge]], 2006, p. 59
However, even in the 18th century, people complained about adulteration in food:
"The bread I eat in London is a deleterious paste, mixed up with chalk, alum and bone ashes, insipid to the taste and destructive to the constitution. The good people are not ignorant of this adulteration; but they prefer it to wholesome bread, because it is whiter than the meal of corn [wheat]. Thus they sacrifice their taste and their health. . . to a most absurd gratification of a misjudged eye; and the miller or the baker is obliged to poison them and their families, in order to live by his profession." – [[Tobias Smollet]], ''[[The Expedition of Humphry Clinker]]'' (1771)[http://www.westonaprice.org/modern-diseases/digestive-disorders/621-against-the-grain.html Weston A.Price: Against the Grain, Section Bread to Feed the Masses]
==Incidents of adulteration== {{See also|List of food contamination incidents}} * In 1981, [[denaturation (food)|denaturated]] [[Colza oil]] was added to [[Olive oil]] in [[Spain]] and 600 people were killed (See [[Toxic oil syndrome]]) * In 1987, [[Beech-Nut]] was fined for violating the US [[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]] by selling flavored sugar water as apple juice.[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1370/is_n5_v22/ai_6495698 Juiceless baby juice leads to full-length justice|FDA Consumer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071210213152/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1370/is_n5_v22/ai_6495698 |date=2007-12-10 }} * In 1997, [[ConAgra Foods]] illegally sprayed water on stored grain to increase its weight.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DE0DC1F38F933A15750C0A961958260 ConAgra Set to Settle Criminal Charges It Increased Weight and Value of Grain – New York Times] * In 2007, samples of [[wheat gluten (food)|wheat gluten]] mixed with [[melamine]], presumably to produce inflated results from tests for protein content, were discovered in the USA. They were found to have come from China. ''(See: [[Chinese protein adulteration]].)'' * In 2008, significant portions of China's [[milk]] supply were found to have been adulterated with melamine. [[Infant formula]] produced from this milk killed at least six children and is believed to have harmed thousands of others. ''(See: [[2008 Chinese milk scandal]].)'' * In 2012, a study in India across 29 states and union territories found that milk was adulterated with detergent, fat, and even [[urea]], and diluted with water. Just 31.5% of samples conformed to FSSAI standards.{{cite news |last=Sinha |first=Kounteya |date=10 January 2012 |title=70% of milk in Delhi, country is adulterated |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/70-of-milk-in-Delhi-country-is-adulterated/articleshow/11429910.cms |newspaper=Times of India |accessdate=23 February 2014}} * In the [[2013 meat adulteration scandal]] in Europe, horsemeat was passed off as beef. ==See also== * [[Surrogate alcohol]]: harmful substances which are used as substitutes for alcoholic beverages ** [[Denatured alcohol]]: alcohol which is deliberately poisoned to discourage its recreational use * [[Ersatz]] * [[Impurity]] * [[Fake food]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{EB1911 poster|Adulteration}} * {{gutenberg|no=19031|name=A Treatise on Adulterations of Food, and Culinary Poisons}} by [[Friedrich Accum]] {{Consumer Food Safety}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Adulteration| ]] [[Category:Doping in sport]] [[Category:Food additives]] [[Category:Food industry]] [[Category:Food safety]] [[Category:Pejoratives]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Edward Daniel Alexander Bagot''' (25 December 1893 – 12 June 1968), generally known as "Alec" or "E. D. A. Bagot" was a South Australian adventurer, polemicist and politician active in the first half of the 20th Century, and related to Captain [[Charles Hervey Bagot]].
==Early life== His father, the Rev. E(dward) Arthur Bagot ( – 19 January 1930) of Kildoon, [[County Kildare]], and mother had arrived in Adelaide on the ''Ormuz'' on 21 July 1891. Mrs Bagot had a daughter at 73 Hill Street, North Adelaide, and the son was born in [[Magill, South Australia|Magill]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25673545 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=27 December 1893 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><!-- not Henley Beach--> on Christmas Day, 1893. In 1894 they moved to Western Australia, where they had another son on 6 November 1895 at [[Cottesloe, Western Australia|Cottesloe Beach]] and in 1899 returned to England, eventually retiring to [[Brighton]].
E. D. A. Bagot was educated at [[Framlingham College|Framlingham]] and [[Lowestoft College|Lowestoft]] Colleges, in [[Suffolk]], joined the [[Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company]], assigned as second wireless operator to the ''[[S.S. Olympic]]'', and was on that ship when she received the fateful last broadcasts of her sister ship ''[[S.S. Titanic|Titanic]]''.
==Military service== At the outbreak of war in 1914 he was in Australia working for the Commonwealth Radio Service (later Postmaster-General's Department) at [[Alberton, South Australia]]. He applied for enlistment several times, and was finally accepted on 11 September 1916, and married Christobel Bollen on 20 September 1916. (Curiously, in his Army enlistment papers he gave his place of birth as [[Lowestoft]], England.)<ref>[http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=3043823 National Archives Service dossier for E. D. A. Bagot]</ref> He joined the Australian Imperial Forces as a lieutenant in the 1st Australian (Wireless) Signals Squadron, led by Major Charles William Marr, and left on the ''Karmala'' for the Middle East on 21 September 1916 and served in India and [[Mesopotamia]], [[Mentioned in Despatches]] in 1918 (once not twice, and contrary to some references he was never awarded a [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]]), promoted to captain on 1 October 1918 and returned to Australia on 14 April, his appointment terminating in Adelaide on 23 May 1919.<ref>http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp</ref>
==Postwar life==
After the war he spent another eight years organising tourist services between [[Iraq]], Persia (now [[Iran]]) and [[Syria]] for the Mesopotamian Trading Agency of Ashar, [[Basrah]]. His wife may have joined him in 1924.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4177380 |title=Classified Advertising. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=16 August 1924 |accessdate=27 March 2012 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He returned to South Australia in 1926 with the intention of setting up a regular service between Adelaide and [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] via [[Oodnadatta, South Australia|Oodnadatta]] and [[Alice Springs, Northern Territory|Alice Springs]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article60937479 |title=Adelaide to Darwin. |newspaper=[[Townsville Daily Bulletin]] |location=Qld. |date=7 April 1926 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He conducted a demonstration run with eight men and four women in three [[Studebaker]] cars and a [[Thornycroft]] truck,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www3.hants.gov.uk/thornycroft/lorries/endurance.htm |title=Thornycroft lorries feats of endurance |access-date=23 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014205811/http://www3.hants.gov.uk/thornycroft/lorries/endurance.htm |archive-date=14 October 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> leaving Adelaide on 18 May and arrived in Darwin on 3 June; left there on 7 June and returned to Adelaide on 25 June, travelling via [[Camooweal, Queensland]] and [[Marree, South Australia]], publicised by Duncan and Fraser (agents for both Thornycroft and Studebaker) and as they were equipped with a short-wave transceiver, gave nightly reports on radio 5CL.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article56567213 |title=Communicating with Overland Motorists |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=29 May 1926 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Despite a second successful round trip that year, Bagot abandoned his idea of regular service when the Commonwealth Government turned down his application for a subsidy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article54821501 |title=North–South Transport. |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=24 November 1926 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=9 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He found employment with [[General Motors]] and in 1930 "Captain Bagot" as he was called by admirers (or "'Alphabetical Bagot' as he was known to the many who disliked him),<ref>Nethercote, J. N. ''Liberalism and the Australian Federation'' p.143 Federation Press, 2001 {{ISBN|1862874026}}</ref> founded the Citizens' League of South Australia, which opposed Unionism, Communism and the White Australia Policy as benefiting the working classes, yet also opposing Fascism. This was the time of the [[Great Depression]] and he also supported the Young People's Employment Council and the Rev. [[Samuel Forsyth (Methodist)|Samuel Forsyth]]'s (1881–1960) Forsyth Industrial Colony "Kuitpo Colony" near [[Kuitpo Forest]], which was training boys as farm workers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32591153 |title=Unemployed Youth |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth |date=2 December 1932 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=12 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The Citizen's League attempted political influence by promising support to political candidates,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59387712 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]] |location=Adelaide |date=28 January 1933 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=3 Section: Advertising |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and was a factor in the election of the Independent candidate [[George Connor (Australian politician)|George Connor]] to the [[South Australian House of Assembly|Assembly]] seat of Alexandra in 1934.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47535894 |title=Independent Wins By-Election |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=12 February 1934 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=9 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In 1933 he founded Wannaway Options Limited, a gold-mining company with ten leases in Western Australia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article74008313 |title=Wannaway Options Limited |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=2 June 1933 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=23 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> A new company, New Milo Gold Mining, was set up to take over the options held by Wannaway which was voluntarily liquidated in August the same year.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article34620402 |title=Mining |newspaper=[[Western Argus|Western Argus (Kalgoorlie, WA : 1916 – 1938)]] |location=Kalgoorlie, WA |date=8 August 1933 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
He was a committee member of the S.P.C.A., one of many organisations supported by Mrs Alec Bagot. He founded the Australian Listeners' League in 1937, with the principal aim of having the Radio Listener's Licence fee halved from one guinea (£1.1s) to 10/6d.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55929558 |title=1,000 Radio Listeners Join League. |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]] |location=Adelaide |date=19 June 1937 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=9 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==Political life== After several abortive attempts to enter parliament, he was elected to the Southern District seat on the [[South Australian Legislative Council]] in a by-election in 1938, largely on his stand against five year parliamentary terms.
When not a full-time political operator, he was employed in the insurance industry in Adelaide<ref name=adb>Lonie, John, [http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/bagot-edward-daniel-5091/text8499 'Bagot, Edward Daniel (1893–1968)'], ''Australian Dictionary of Biography'', National Centre of Biography, Australian National University, accessed 26 March 2012</ref> then in 1943 moved to [[Broken Hill, New South Wales|Broken Hill]], from where he joined the [[Government Insurance Office of New South Wales]]. He was promoted and moved to Sydney, where amongst other duties he edited the in-house magazine ''Security'', retiring in 1963.<ref name=adb/> and wrote a well-received biography of [[George S. Coppin]]. His wife was a close friend of Coppin's daughter Lucy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55787627 |title=Women's Interests |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]] |location=Adelaide |date=4 August 1951 |accessdate=13 July 2012 |page=32 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==Family== He married Christobel Bollen on 20 September 1916. Her father, Dr. Christopher Bollen (29 July 1866 – 12 September 1952) of "Clovelly", Woodville Road, [[Woodville, South Australia|Woodville]] then [[Fitzroy, South Australia]], was notable as having possibly the longest practising life of any Australian medical practitioner.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47435527 |title=Death of Dr. Chris Bollen |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=13 September 1952 |accessdate=26 March 2012 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Mrs Alec Bagot, as she was generally known, was a keen actor and was involved in many charitable organisations.
They had one son, Edward Christopher (5 January 1922 – 14 January 1944), who enlisted in the RAAF in March 1941, and left for England in September 1942 became a Pilot Officer, flying Lancaster bombers in the Pathfinder force for Bomber Command over Germany and was lost, reportedly when his plane crashed near [[Salzgitter|Watenstedt]] in the [[Braunschweig|Brunswick]] area. In the absence of evidence, his mother never abandoned hope of his survival and spent years searching for the facts surrounding his disappearance, to the discomfort of the Air Force's Missing, Research and Enquiry Service.
Their first home was "Clovelly", [[Woodville, South Australia]] then until 1937 "Wellington House", Wellington Square, [[North Adelaide, South Australia|North Adelaide]]; then 90 Jeffcott Street, North Adelaide (with a summer residence in [[Stirling, South Australia|Stirling West]]). Their Sydney home was initially at 104 Elizabeth Bay Road, [[Elizabeth Bay, New South Wales|Elizabeth Bay]].
==Sources== Information regarding E. D. A. Bagot's military service and E. C. Bagot's death and other details were obtained from the National Archives of Australia online.<ref>[http://www.naa.gov.au/collection/using/search/ Search the collection – National Archives of Australia]</ref>
==Graphics== *A caricature of him by John Henry Chinner is held by the National Library of Australia.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an6054497 Digital Collections – Pictures – Chinner, J. H. (John Henry), 1865–1933. [Caricature portrait of Captain Bagot] [picture]]</ref> *Group photograph of 1st Signals Squadron is at http://cas.awm.gov.au/photograph/P00562.066<!-- out of copyright-->
==Bibliography== *''Roaming Around: Memoirs of a Marconi operator'', (unpublished) *''Coppin the Great : father of the Australian theatre'', Melbourne Univ. Press, 1965.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bagot, E. D. A.}} [[Category:Independent members of the Parliament of South Australia]] [[Category:Members of the South Australian Legislative Council]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Australian people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Politicians from Adelaide]] [[Category:1893 births]] [[Category:1968 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Australian politicians]]

{{notability|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = AlixPartners LLP | logo = AlixPartners Logo.png | type = [[Partnership]] |founder = Jay Alix |foundation = {{start date and age|1981}} | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|U.S.]] | key_people = Simon Freakley (CEO)<ref>http://www.consultancy.uk/news/2431/simon-freakley-new-chief-executive-of-alixpartners</ref> | num_employees = 1600+ | industry = [[Management consulting]] | area_served = Global | homepage = [http://www.alixpartners.com/ AlixPartners.com] }}
'''AlixPartners''' sometimes referred to as '''Alix Partners''' is a [[Management consulting|consulting firm]] best known for its work in the [[Turnaround management|turnaround]] space.<ref>Merx, Katie. "Thinking Big Thoughts." ''Crain's Detroit Business'' 19.36 (2003): 18. ''Regional Business News.'' Web. 29 May 2013.</ref> The firm was founded by Jay Alix in 1981 in order to handle the turnaround of Electrical Specialties Co., and has since moved into a more traditional consulting space, grown to a staff of over 1000, and added office locations throughout North America, Europe, and Asia.<ref>Henderson, Tom. "Alixpartners Deal Gives Equity To Firm's Managers." ''Crain's Detroit Business'' 22.32 (2006): 1. ''Regional Business News.'' Web. 29 May 2013.</ref>
AlixPartners' work includes enterprise improvement consulting, financial advisory services, information management services, and executing turnarounds of distressed and healthy companies. AlixPartners has been involved in several high-profile turnaround and bankruptcy assignments including GM's [[Saab Automobile|Saab]] division,<ref>New York Times, "G.M. Hires AlixPartners to Wind Down Saab", Jan. 8, 2009, http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/01/08/gm-hires-alixpartners-to-wind-down-saab/</ref> Kodak,<ref>New York Times, "Kodak Replaces Its Restructuring Chief", Jan 23, 2012, http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/01/23/kodak-replaces-its-restructuring-chief/</ref> Barney's New York,<ref>New York Times, "Barneys, Debt-Laden, Is Weighing Restructuring", Feb 8, 2012, http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/02/08/barneys-debt-laden-is-weighing-restructuring/</ref> and [[JC Penney]].<ref>[http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887323551004578441033948964810.html Penney Works With AlixPartners on Cost Savings], Wall Street Journal, April 23, 2013</ref> The firm's managing directors are frequently cited as topic experts in business publications such as Bloomberg, the Financial Times, CNBC, and Fox Business.
AlixPartners competes in the traditional consulting space with firms including [[McKinsey & Company]], the [[Boston Consulting Group]], and [[Bain & Company]], they also compete with turnaround specialty firms such as [[FTI Consulting]], [[Alvarez and Marsal]], [[Berkeley Research Group]], Capstone Advisory Group, and Hilco Global.<ref>http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.Hilco_Trading_LLC.139018ea27511665.html</ref>{{citation needed|date=May 2013}}
In 2006, private equity firm [[Hellman & Friedman]] invested in AlixPartners.<ref>[http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2006/08/04/turnaround-firm-alixpartners-is-sold/ Turnaround Firm AlixPartners Is Sold]</ref> In 2012, [[CVC Capital Partners]] acquired AlixPartners from Hellman & Friedman.<ref>[http://finance.fortune.cnn.com/2012/07/02/private-equity-deals-162/ M&A: July 2, 2012]</ref>
==External links== *AlixPartners homepage: http://www.alixpartners.com/en/Home.aspx
==References==
<references />
[[Category:Consulting firms]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]]

{{Infobox company | name = Argosy Book Store | logo = Argosy Book Store.jpeg | logo_size = 287px | foundation = {{Start date|1925}} | founder = Louis Cohen | owner = Judith Lowry, Naomi Hample, Adina Cohen, Ben Lowry | location_city = [[New York City]] | location_country = United States | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Retailing|Specialty retail]] | products = Out-of-print and rare books; antique maps and prints; autographs & manuscripts | num_employees = 17 | homepage = http://www.argosybooks.com/ }}
The '''Argosy Book Store''' is [[New York City]]’s oldest [[independent bookstore]]. Located at 116 East [[59th Street (Manhattan)|59th Street]] in [[Midtown Manhattan|Midtown]] [[Manhattan]], it occupies an entire six-story [[townhouse]] with various sales floors specializing in [[edition (books)|first editions]], [[Americana]], leather bindings, antique maps and prints, and autographs.<ref>{{Citation | last = Thomas | first = Michael | title = Volumes of Praise: One Loyal Customer's Appreciation for the Argosy Book Shop | pages = 145 | magazine = [[Quest (lifestyle magazine)|Quest]] | date = October 2005 }}</ref> The store, also noted for a wide selection of bargain books, has its own framing and shipping departments and owns a large warehouse in [[Brooklyn]].
==History== The Argosy was founded in 1925 by Louis Cohen,<ref>[http://www.salon.com/2011/05/15/trazzler_slide_show_beautiful_bookstores/slide_show/9/ "The world's most inspiring bookstores"] ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]''</ref> who picked the name, in part, because it started with the letter “A” and would be listed early in telephone directories.<ref>{{Citation | last = Nelson | first = Sara | title = A Family Affair: Book lovers flock to the Argosy Book Store, a thriving New York cultural institution presided over by savvy sisters | newspaper = ''[[Publishers Weekly]] Book Life'' | pages = 27 | date = December 2006 – January 2007 }}</ref> Originally located in the old Bible House on [[Park Avenue (Manhattan)|Fourth Avenue]]’s famed “Book Row,” it moved to 114 East 59th Street in the 1930s<ref> {{Citation | last = Chernofsky | first = Jacob | title = Louis Cohen and the Argosy Book Store | newspaper = [[AB Bookman's Weekly]] | pages = 1509–1510 | date = April 15, 1991 }}</ref> and then moved next door to its current address in 1964 when the previous building was replaced with a skyscraper. Cohen’s wife, Ruth Shevin, managed the store’s art gallery into her 90s<ref name="shrine to books past">[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/13/books/a-shrine-to-books-past-clings-to-independence.html "A shrine to books past clings to independence"] ''[[The New York Times]]'' (October 13, 1997)</ref> and worked with several other family members over the years. Now in its third generation of family ownership, the store is operated by Cohen’s three daughters and a grandson.<ref name="midtown bookstores"> {{cite web | last = Molarsky | first = Mona | title = Favorite Midtown bookstores east of Fifth | publisher = ''[[Examiner.com]]'' | date = February 16, 2009 <!-- | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120928024511/http://www.examiner.com/article/favorite-midtown-bookstores-east-of-fifth | archive-date = 28 September 2012--> }}</ref>
Since its inception, the Argosy has worked with many prominent customers, including President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], who ordered books from an early catalogue, and later First Lady [[Jacqueline Kennedy]], who needed help stocking the [[White House]] library with Americana.<ref name="shrine to books past" /> President [[Bill Clinton]] has been a regular customer <ref>{{Citation | last = Barron | first = James | title = Boldface Names | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = December 25, 2001 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/25/nyregion/boldface-names-831840.html }} </ref><ref>{{Citation | title = Page Six: Sightings | newspaper = [[The New York Post]] | date = December 9, 2004 | url = http://entertainment.uk.myway.com/celebgossip/pgsix/id/12_09_2004_11.html }} </ref> ever since the owners restored his flood-damaged collection of books in [[Chappaqua, New York|Chappaqua]], New York.<ref>{{Citation | last = Barron | first = James | last2 = Waldman | first2 = Amy | title = Boldface Names | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = July 31, 2001 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/31/nyregion/boldface-names-483583.html }}</ref> Other high-profile customers have included [[Michael Jackson]],<ref name="shrine to books past" /> [[Stephen Sondheim]],<ref name="shrine to books past" /> [[Princess Grace]],<ref>{{Citation | last = Reynolds | first = Tripp | title = Little Shop of Treasures: New York's Argosy Bookshop Is A Paradise For Collectors Of All Kinds | newspaper = [[The Chicago Tribune]] | date = April 4, 1995 | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-04-04/features/9504040005_1_rare-maps-upton-sinclair-cabinets }}</ref> [[Sally Field]],<ref>{{Citation | last = Kachka | first = Boris | title = Sally Field Spent a Decade Getting Into Character for Lincoln | newspaper = [[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]] | date = November 11, 2012 | url = http://www.vulture.com/2012/11/sally-field-on-being-lincolns-first-lady.html }}</ref> [[Donatella Versace]],<ref>{{Citation | last = Kling | first = Cynthia | title = Shortlist: Donatella Versace | newspaper = [[Elle (magazine)|Elle Decor]] | url = http://www.elledecor.com/design-decorate/shortlist-donatella-versace#slide-5 }}</ref> [[Oriana Fallaci]],<ref>{{Citation | title = Page Six: Sightings | newspaper = [[The New York Post]] | date = December 20, 2005 | url = http://entertainment.ca.myway.com/celebgossip/pgsix/id/12_20_2005_11.html }}</ref> and [[Kevin Rudd]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Barron | first = James | title = City Room: A Prime Minister and a Roosevelt | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = September 24, 2009 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE0D91430F937A1575AC0A96F9C8B63 }} </ref> [[Patti Smith]] was briefly an employee in 1967.<ref> {{cite web | title = Jonathan Lethem & Patti Smith | publisher = [[PEN American Center]] | date = November 3, 2010 | url = http://www.pen.org/transcript-conversation/jonathan-lethem-patti-smith | format = interview }} </ref>
In October 2012 the Argosy suffered extensive damage during [[Hurricane Sandy]], when bricks dislodged from the 32nd story of the adjacent building and crashed through the store’s roof. The resulting flood affected the top two floors and destroyed many historical artifacts, including acts of congress signed by [[Thomas Jefferson]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Barron | first = James | title = Storm’s Damage Extends to Nation’s History | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = November 15, 2012 | url = http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/15/storms-damage-extends-to-nations-history/ }} </ref> The store made a full recovery by the fall of 2013.
==In popular culture==
The Argosy, known for its elegant old-world interior,<ref>{{Citation | last = Shapiro | first = Gary | title = An Uptown Book Oasis | newspaper = [[The New York Sun]] | date = February 14, 2006 | url = http://www.nysun.com/arts/uptown-book-oasis/27546/ }} </ref> has been used as a setting for movies and TV dramas, including ''[[The Front]]'' with [[Woody Allen]], ''[[Law & Order (franchise)|Law and Order]]'', and ''[[Person of Interest (TV series)|Person of Interest]]''.<ref name="midtown bookstores" /> Alfred Hitchcock’s film Vertigo also features a bookstore of the same name situated in San Francisco. It has also been used as a background for fashion shoots and television interviews.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.argosybooks.com/ Official '''Argosy Book Store''' website] *[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/06/23/the-book-refuge Article in The New Yorker: Argosy Book Store] *[http://articles.latimes.com/2011/sep/04/travel/la-tr-nypl-20110904 Article in the Los Angeles Times] *[https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/obituaries/louis-cohen-87-rarities-expert-and-founder-of-argosy-book-shop.html Obituary for Louis Cohen in the New York Times] *[http://www.unav.es/nuestrotiempo/es/cultura/tinta-papel-y-vida Spanish article in Nuestro Tiempo]

{{Infobox journal | title = Asia | cover = Asia_Magazine_Cover_October_1921.jpg | caption = | former_name = Journal of the American Asiatic Association | abbreviation = Asia | discipline = | peer-reviewed = | language = English | editor = Louis D. Froelick
John Foord
Richard J. Walsh (1934-1942)
Pearl S. Buck (1942-1946) | publisher = American Asiatic Association
East and West Association (1942-1946) | country = United States | history = 1898-1946 | frequency = Monthly | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | ISSNlabel = | ISSN = | eISSN = | CODEN = | JSTOR = | LCCN = | OCLC =760765404
1514415 | website = | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | boxwidth = }} '''''Asia''''' was an [[United States|American]] [[magazine]] in the 1920s and 1930s that featured reporting about [[Asia]] and its people, including the [[Far East]], [[Southeast Asia]], [[South Asia]], and the [[Middle East]]. From 1934 to 1946, it was edited by [[Richard J. Walsh]], with extensive contributions from his wife, [[Pearl S. Buck]]. Under their influence, the journal published many prominent Asian literary and political figures and American authorities. In 1946, after many years of financial trouble, it was merged into a new journal, ''United Nations World''. ==Origins and development== ''Asia'' magazine was established by the [[American Asiatic Association]] in 1898 as ''Journal of the American Asiatic Association''. An editorial in the ''Journal'' explained: "The ignorance of our people in regard to the countries of the Far East is unquestionably a serious obstacle to the legitimate extension of American influence. .''Journal of the American Asiatic Association''. Asia: 17.1 (March 1917). [https://books.google.com/books?id=SQhZAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&vq=irgnorance+of+our+people#v=onepage&q&f=false]. In 1917 [[Willard Dickerman Straight|Willard Straight]], who had been involved in promoting American trade and investment in Korea and China since the turn of the century, and his wife, [[Dorothy Payne Whitney|Dorothy Payne Whitney Straight]], bought the magazine and renamed it ''Asia''. and continued its publication as a popular journal of commerce and travel. The Straights also were co-founders of ''[[The New Republic]]'' magazine."Records of Asia Magazine" RG 4, pp. 207 208, "Papers of Pearl S. Buck," [http://www.psbi.org/document.doc?id=533 ] When Willard Straight died of influenza in 1918, his widow took over publication of the magazine. She married [[Leonard K. Elmhirst]] in 1925. The editors included [[Louis D. Froelick]] and [[John Foord]], and associate editors [[Gertrude Emerson Sen|Gertrude Emerson]] and Marietta Neff. [[Elsie Weil]], who joined the staff about 1920, was the long time managing editor.[[Frank H. McIntosh (artist)|Frank H. McIntosh]] painted many of the covers.[http://www.askart.com/AskART/M/frank_mcintosh/frank_mcintosh.aspx Ask Art] ==Under Richard Walsh and Pearl S. Buck== In January 1934, although ownership remained unchanged, [[Richard J. Walsh]], head of [[John Day Company|John Day publishers]] published his first issue as editor. He announced that the magazine would no longer be a tourist handbook, and despite objections from some readers, the magazine was shifted from advertising luxury goods, travel and promotion of American commerce in the Orient to discussion of international affairs and current Asian culture and literature. In the first editorial Walsh promised readers a wide range of topics and views. The magazine's political stance changed as well. Walsh wrote that it would "look upon Communism as objectively as upon art, and bring to religious concepts as open a mind as we bring to economic problems." Walsh soon brought his new wife, [[Pearl S. Buck]] into the editorial process. {{sfnb|Conn|1996| p= 159-160, 171-173}} In the following years, Asia underwent revolution and war. Walsh, as publisher of John Day, and Buck, as America's most influential writer about Asia, attracted and recruited a new range of Asian and American writers, many of whom promoted an anti-colonial agenda, such as support for Indian independence, and anti-racist program. Subscriptions rose as Americans become more worried about the oncoming [[Second Sino-Japanese War]]. Writers included [[William Ernest Hocking]], the Harvard liberal theologian; [[Hu Shih]], leader of China's [[New Culture Movement]]; [[Owen Lattimore]], the emerging authority on Central Asia; [[Lin Yutang]]; [[Jawaharlal Nehru]], the Indian independence leader; and reporters such as [[Nathaniel Peffer]]; [[Edgar Snow]], [[Nym Wales]], and [[Theodore H. White]], who reported from the front line on China before World War II. Buck wrote a regular book review column titled “Asia Book Shelf.” The magazine recruited corresponding editors to gather articles, including [[Gertrude Emerson Sen]] in India and [[Harold John Timperley|H.J. Timperley]], an Australian journalist in China.{{sfnb|Conn|1996| p= 159-160, 171-173}} In 1941, Walsh and Buck bought the magazine from the Elmhirsts. They changed the name to ''Asia and the Americas'' in November 1942, and Buck assumed the editorship. She continued her attacks on imperialism, particularly British, and offered strong support for colonial independence movements.{{sfnb|Conn|1996| p= 243}} With the end of the war in 1945, however, Americans lost interest in Asia and the magazine suffered a financial crisis. Buck resigned as editor in 1947 merged the magazine with ''[[Free World (magazine)|Free World]]'' and ''Inter-American'' to form a new journal,''United Nations World''.{{sfnb|Conn|1996| p = 297-298}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References and further reading== * {{cite book |last = Conn |first = Peter J. |year = 1996 |title = Pearl S. Buck: A Cultural Biography |publisher = Cambridge University Press| location = Cambridge England; New York |isbn = 0521560802 |ref = harv}} * "Chapter Three: The American Asiatic Association and the Imperialist Imaginary of the American Pacific," in {{cite book |last = Eperjesi |first = John R. |year = 2005 |title = The Imperialist Imaginary: Visions of Asia and the Pacific in American Culture |publisher = University Press of New England| location = Hanover, NH|url=https://www.loc.gov/catdir/toc/ecip0421/2004019242.html |isbn = 1584654341 |ref = none}}, 86-104 ==External links== * [http://www.askart.com/AskART/M/frank_mcintosh/frank_mcintosh.aspx Newsstand: 1925: ''Asia Magazine''] * [http://msnyder.typepad.com/the_labyrinth/2009/05/dreamy-art-deco-magazine-covers-by-frank-mcintosh.htmlDreamy Art Deco Magazine Covers for Asia Magazine by Frank McIntosh]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [http://www.msnyder.typepad.com/ Midori Snyder in the Labyrinth] (May 14, 2009) [[Category:Defunct magazines of the United States]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1898]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1946]] [[Category:American monthly magazines]] [[Category:American business magazines]] [[Category:Tourism magazines]]

'''Caravan capitalism''' is the act of travelling between countries as wages increase. It takes its name from an alternative name for the [[travel trailer]], and was first coined by [[Germany|German]] minister of finance [[Peer Steinbrück]]<ref name="library">{{cite web|url=http://library.fes.de/pdf-files/bueros/stockholm/05599.pdf|title=Caravan capitalism in the North? – The Case of Stora Enso Dismissals in Finland|publisher=Fes.de|accessdate=20 November 2013}} s.a. [[Stora Enso]]</ref> in March 2007 after [[Nokia]] signed a memorandum with [[Cluj County]] Council, [[Romania]] to open a new plant near the city in [[Jucu]] commune<ref name="Romania">{{cite press release|url=http://www.nokia.com/A4136001?newsid=1114420|title=Nokia to set up a new mobile device factory in Romania|date=26 March 2007|publisher=Nokia Corporation|accessdate=14 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2007/03/22/nokia_to_open_cell_phone_plant_near_cluj/|title=Nokia to open cell phone plant near Cluj|date=22 March 2007|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Boston.com|accessdate=14 May 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080507194303/http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2007/03/22/nokia_to_open_cell_phone_plant_near_cluj/ |archivedate = 7 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Nokia+to+build+mobile+phone+plant+in+Romania/1135226144930|title=Nokia to build mobile phone plant in Romania|date=27 March 2007|work=Helsingin Sanomat|accessdate=14 May 2008}}</ref> closing the [[Bochum]], Germany factory, disgusting them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,3076534,00.html|title=German Politicians Return Cell Phones Amid Nokia Boycott Calls|date=18 January 2008|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|accessdate=22 March 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/0,1518,540699,00.html|title=German State Demands €60 Million from Nokia|date=11 March 2008|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|accessdate=22 March 2009}}</ref>

'''Charles Edward Frosst''' (1867–1948) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] businessman who founded the pharmaceutical company [[Charles E. Frosst & Co.]] in 1899 which was acquired by [[Merck & Co.]] in 1965 to become [[Merck Frosst Canada Inc.]]
Charles Frosst is interred in the [[Mount Royal Cemetery]] in Montreal.

/* "Hook IP" */ [[Patent]]s are by definition not "secret". In fact, the very original of the word "patent" is as an [[antonym]] of "secret" (as in: "we don't make it secret, we make it patent, but you require a license from us").
revision.text:
'''Compliance and Robustness''', sometimes abbreviated as '''C&R''', refers to the legal structure or regime underlying a [[Digital Rights Management]] (DRM) system. In many cases, the C&R regime for a given DRM is provided by the same company that sells the DRM solution. For example, [[RealNetworks]] Helix or [[Microsoft]] [[Windows Media DRM]].
However, for standardised DRM systems, it is fairly common for a separate body to be established to run the C&R regime.
== Elements == === C&R Body === The legal entity that establishes and maintains the regime. Usually this will be a [[joint venture]] or forum with representation from multiple companies, structured in such as way as to avoid accusations of [[antitrust]] violations. The nature of the business is that such bodies will generally be composed of manufacturers and content owners, with little or no direct representation from consumer advocates.
=== Trust Model === The C&R body is responsible for ensuring a chain of trust, such that the original content provider is sufficiently satisfied that their content will remain adequately secure throughout all future links in the chain. This may include export of content from one DRM system to another.
To meet this requirement, it is normal that any device planning to receive DRMed content is required to validate that it meets the C&R requirements, and this is usually done using a [[device certificate]] of some kind. The issuance of such certificates is the stamp of approval for both the manufacturer and the device.
If two devices can verify that they both have trusted certificates, they can then reasonably expect that content passed between them will remain secure.
=== Compliance Rules === In many cases there will be gaps, ambiguities or options left open in a DRM technical specification. The C&R regime must clarify exactly how a compliant device is to behave in these cases. For example, a compliance rule may define which other types of interfaces are acceptable on a device, something that the technical specification itself will never do.
=== Robustness Rules === The most controversial aspect of C&R is the agreement on how to ensure that a device is sufficiently robust at resisting attacks. These rules may require that certain elements are implemented only in hardware, or run on secure CPUs, or that the code must not be available as open source. Manufacturers then have to satisfy the C&R body that they meet this requirement before they are granted access to the certificates needed to establish their products as trusted.
=== "Hook IP" === One particular trick that is often used is to include some [[patent]]ed technology, often as part of the trust establishment mechanism. This means that anyone wanting to implement the DRM in a way that will work with others is forced to license these patents. A condition of obtaining such a license is to follow the rules of the C&R regime itself. Thus a C&R body has a 20-year window to pursue legal measures against a "rogue" implementation on the grounds of patent violation, rather than having to rely on a [[DMCA]]-style regulation provided by the relevant government. The need to license hook IP patents also impacts anyone thinking of building a product covered by the [[GPL]].
One well-known example of a system employing such Hook IP is the DVB Common Scrambling Algorithm [[DVB-CSA]], which though standardised by [[ETSI]], includes patented elements that are only licensed to approved [[Conditional access]] systems vendors who agree to maintain the secrecy and integrity of the algorithm in their chip designs.
== Examples == * [[OMA DRM]] is governed by the [http://www.cm-la.com/ CMLA] C&R regime * [[DTCP-IP]] is governed by the [http://www.dtcp.com/ DTLA] C&R regime
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Digital rights management]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox newspaper | logo = Dziennik Gazeta Prawna.png | image = | caption = | type = [[Daily newspaper]] (Monday to Saturday) | format = | owners = Infor Biznes
Ringier Axel Springer Media AG | founder = Infor Biznes | publisher = Infor Biznes | editor = | chiefeditor = Krzysztof Jedlak | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = {{start date and age|2009|9|1|df=yes}} | political = [[Centrist]]
[[Center-right]] | language = [[Polish language|Polish]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Warsaw]] | circulation = 53,058 (August 2014) | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.dziennik.pl/ ''Dziennik Gazeta Prawna''] }} '''''Dziennik Gazeta Prawna''''' (meaning ''Daily Legal Newspaper'' in English) is a German-Swiss owned Polish newspaper, headquartered in [[Warsaw]] and published in [[Poland]] from Monday to Saturday. The paper focuses on economic and legal affairs. ==History== The paper was launched as a result of the merger between ''[[Dziennik Polska-Europa-Świat|Dziennik]]'' and ''Gazeta Prawna'' (''Legal Newspaper'' in English) in September 2009.{{cite web|title=Dziennik Gazeta Prawna|url=http://www.publicitas.com/switzerland/media-solutions/factsheet/?PARAM1=IWQGW2&title=dziennik-gazeta-prawna#.UkaMV2RJVgs|work=Publicitas|accessdate=28 September 2013}}{{cite book|author=Katarzyna Pokorna-Ignatowicz|title=The Polish Media System 1989 - 2011|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mMI-cOkSfCEC&pg=PA64|accessdate=28 September 2013|year=2012|publisher=Krakowskie Towarzystwo Eduk|isbn=978-83-7571-217-9|pages=64}} Of them, ''Dziennik'' was a daily while the latter was a special legal paper. The publisher of ''Dziennik'', Ringier Axel Springer, sold it to Infor Biznes, the publisher of ''Gazeta Prawna''.{{cite web|title=Country profile - Poland|url=http://www.mediadb.eu/en/data-base/eu-laenderportraets/polen.html?cHash=2e1dc49af2d8e87a75cc4846cfb41516&type=98|work=ifM|accessdate=28 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218124246/http://www.mediadb.eu/en/data-base/eu-laenderportraets/polen.html?cHash=2e1dc49af2d8e87a75cc4846cfb41516&type=98|archivedate=18 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Press market in Poland A.D. 2010|url=https://depot.ceon.pl/bitstream/handle/123456789/312/adamski%20press%20market%20in%20Poland.pdf?sequence=1|work=CeON Repository|accessdate=10 December 2013|author=Andrzej Adamski}} Ringier Axel Springer Media AG owns a 49% share of Infor Biznes, publisher of the daily.{{cite web|title=Countries - Poland|url=http://www.ringieraxelspringer.com/en/company/countries/poland|work=Ringier Axel Springer|accessdate=28 September 2013}} ''Dziennik Gazeta Prawna'' was headquartered in [[Warsaw]] following the merger. Michał Kobosko was the [[editor-in-chief]] of the paper from 2009 to 2010.{{cite web|title=Dziennik Gazeta Prawna|url=http://www.presseurop.eu/en/content/source-profile/49911-dziennik-gazeta-prawna|work=Presseurop|date=15 December 2011}} From June 2016 the editor-in-chief is Krzysztof Jedlak.{{Cite web|url=http://www.wirtualnemedia.pl/artykul/jadwiga-sztabinska-rezygnuje-krzysztof-jedlak-naczelnym-dziennika-gazety-prawnej|title=Jadwiga Sztabińska rezygnuje, Krzysztof Jedlak naczelnym "Dziennika Gazety Prawnej"|author=Tomasz Wojtas| date=22 April 2016|work=Wirtualne Media|accessdate=29 June 2016|language=pl}} The circulation of ''Dziennik Gazeta Prawna'' was 118,206 copies in 2009. It was 99,582 copies in 2010 and 91,554 in 2011.{{cite web|title=National newspapers total circulation|url=http://www.ifabc.org/site/assets/media/National-Newspapers_total-circulation_IFABC_09-07-12.xls|work=International Federation of Audit Bureaux of Circulations|accessdate=2 December 2014}} In a readership study covered the period of April through September 2011 it was found that the paper had the score of 2.24%, making it the seventh most read paper in Poland. The estimated circulation for the daily in 2012 was 82,055 copies. In February 2013 its circulation was 74,150 copies. Its print and e-edition circulation was 53,058 copies in August 2014.{{cite web|title=Circulation of dailies|url=https://www.teleskop.org.pl/zkdp/publicPackage.xls?P=523&ln=en|work=Teleskop|accessdate=2 December 2014}} ==Content and political stance== The major focus for ''Dziennik Gazeta Prawna'' is economic and legal affairs.{{cite web|title=Professor Bernd Raffelhüschen in Warsaw on 20 January 2010|url=http://www.fiwi1.uni-freiburg.de/downloads/sonstiges/warsaw_press_overview.pdf|work=University of Freiburg|accessdate=28 September 2013}}{{cite web|title=Miller Canfield Ranked #1 Mid-Sized Law Firm in Poland by Leading Legal Publication|url=http://www.millercanfield.com/news-1057.html|work=Miller Canfield|accessdate=28 September 2013|date=20 May 2013}} It employed three different colors for its three main sections: white for news, yellow for tax and legal affairs and salmon for business and finance news until 2010. Later salmon-colored section was integrated into main section. On Fridays it covers special features on television, culture and arts. ''Dziennik Gazeta Prawna'' has a [[centrist]] and [[center-right]] stance.{{cite journal|author=Aleksandra Sójka|title=Poland – a Surveillance Eldorado? Security, Privacy, and New Technologies in Polish Leading Newspapers (2010-2013)|journal=Seconomics|date=October 2013|url=http://www.soc.cas.cz/sites/default/files/soubory/poland_-_a_surveillance_eldorado.pdf|accessdate=24 January 2015|location=Prague}}{{cite web|title=The Euro Crisis, Media Coverage, and Perceptions of Europe within the EU|url=https://reutersinstitute.politics.ox.ac.uk/fileadmin/documents/discussion/National_Report_Poland.pdf|work=Reuters Institute|accessdate=28 September 2013|format=Report|year=2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002133316/https://reutersinstitute.politics.ox.ac.uk/fileadmin/documents/discussion/National_Report_Poland.pdf|archivedate=2 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Polish media websites|url=http://port.igrs.sas.ac.uk/languages/pol/resourcespol/cultinst|work=Port|accessdate=28 September 2013}} The paper is also a [[liberal conservative]] publication.{{cite web|title=Dziennik Gazeta Prawna|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/home/medienindex/media_articles/?frommedia=4025|work=Euro Topics|accessdate=8 October 2013}} ==See also== [[List of newspapers in Poland]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://www.dziennik.pl/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dziennik Gazeta Prawna}} [[Category:2009 establishments in Poland]] [[Category:Business newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Warsaw]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Poland]] [[Category:Polish-language newspapers]] [[Category:Publications established in 2009]]

revision.text:
[[Lieutenant Colonel]] '''Edmund Graves Meredith Cape''', [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] (August 7, 1878 – September 28, 1962) was the founding President of E.G.M. Cape & Co., Engineers and Contractors of [[Montreal]], and a Governor of the [[Montreal General Hospital]]. He raised and commanded the 3rd [[Artillery battery|Battery]], Canadian Siege Artillery, and was later appointed Commanding Officer of the 2nd Medium Brigade, [[Royal Regiment of Canadian Artillery]]. His home on Redpath Crescent was one of the last houses put up in the [[Golden Square Mile]].<ref>[http://www.imtl.org/montreal/image.php?id=6771 Edmund Graves Meredith Cape House]</ref>
==Early life== Born at [[Hamilton, Ontario]], he was the son of John Cape (1841–1908) and Margaret Kittson (1843–1887), daughter of William Henry Kittson (1810–1882), Collector of Customs at Hamilton. He took his middle names from the family of his maternal grandmother, Harriet Meredith, sister of [[Edmund Allen Meredith]]. His maternal grandfather, William Kittson, was a stepson of [[Alexander Henry the elder|Alexander Henry]] and brother of [[Norman Kittson]]. Educated at Hamilton and [[McGill University]] ([[Bachelor of Applied Science|B.A.Sc.]], 1898).
==Career== He started his career as the Assistant [[Engineer]] of the [[Lake Superior]] Power Company at [[Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario|Sault Ste. Marie]]. He was promoted to Chief Engineer during the construction of the [[Canada Car Company]], and afterwards practised for some years as a [[Civil engineer|Civil Engineer]] at [[Montreal]]. In 1908, he founded E.G.M. Cape & Co., Engineers and Contractors of Montreal, which still exists today with the head office at [[Toronto]]. He retired as Chairman of the Board in 1958. He was a member of the [[Engineering Institute of Canada]] and of the [[Montreal Board of Trade]]. He was a Governor of the [[Montreal General Hospital]] and the Western General Hospital.<ref>[http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/encyclopedia/EdmundGravesMeredithCape.htm The Quebec History Encyclopedia]</ref>
==First World War== In the autumn of 1915, Major Cape of the [[2nd Field Regiment, Royal Canadian Artillery]] raised and commanded 3rd [[Artillery battery|Battery]], Canadian Siege [[Artillery]] and took them to Europe. After further training in [[England]], in {{nowrap|June 1916}}, Cape accompanied the Battery to [[France]]. Cape fought in the [[Battle of the Somme]] and was wounded at the [[Battle of Vimy Ridge]]. He was twice mentioned in [[Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig|Douglas Haig]]'s [[Mentioned in Despatches|Despatches]] for distinguished service under enemy fire. He was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] In 1920, upon reorganization of the [[Canadian Militia]], [[Lieutenant-colonel (Canada)|Lieutenant Colonel]] Cape was appointed [[Commanding officer|Commanding Officer]] of the 2nd Medium Brigade, [[Montreal]].<ref>[http://www.canadaveteranshallofvalour.com/CapeEGM.htm Canada Veterans Hall of Valour]</ref>
==Family== In 1908, Cape married Lillian Guest Smith of [[Montreal]]. They had three sons and one daughter,
*[[Brigadier General]] John Meredith Cape [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (1910–2005) of the [[Royal Regiment of Canadian Artillery]]. Educated at [[Selwyn House School]], [[Trinity College School]], [[McGill University]] and the [[Royal Military College of Canada]]. Succeeded his father as Chairman of E.G.M. Cape & Co. In 1936, he married Mary Elizabeth Ogilvie, daughter of Lieutenant Colonel Gavin Lang Ogilvie (youngest son of [[William Watson Ogilvie]]) and his wife Mary Gzowski, granddaughter of [[Casimir Gzowski|Sir Casimir Gzowski]]. *Margaret Meredith Cape. Known as Peggy, in 1935 she married Robert Reford MacDougall, son of [[Hartland MacDougall]] and his wife Edith, daughter of [[Robert Wilson Reford, Sr.|Robert Wilson Reford]]. Her husband was a brother-in-law of [[Hartland Molson]].<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s5ouAAAAIBAJ&sjid=np8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6775,6514472&dq=peggy+macdougall&hl=en Montreal Gazette, Facts & Fancies, 1966]</ref> *Edmund Vimy Meredith Cape (1919–1938). Educated at [[Trinity College School]] and in Switzerland. He drowned in icy waters after a [[canoe]] accident while fishing in [[Quebec]].<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kokxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bqgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6748,659164&dq=edmund+cape+montreal&hl=en Montreal Gazette, September 6, 1938]</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lIkxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bqgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6563,883866&dq=meredith-cape&hl=en Montreal Gazette, September 8, 1938]</ref> *David George Meredith Cape (1923-2015). Educated at Lower Canada College and McGill University, Lieutenant, The Black Watch (Royal Highland Regiment) of Canada, MD, founded and practiced medicine (anaesthesiology) at the Lakeshore General Hospital, Pointe Claire, Que. until 2008. In 1945, he married Anne Colhoun Duncanson, daughter of Brig. Andrew E. Duncanson, DSO, OBE, and his wife, Annie Colhoun, divorced 1969, married Sharon Power in 1969, divorced 1982, married Helene Papachristidis Holden, daughter of shipowner, Phrixos Basil Papachristidis, and his wife, Mariette Vachon in 1995.
Cape was a member of the St. James's; Mount Royal; Forest and Stream; [[Montreal Hunt]]; Montreal Racquet; Montreal Indoor Tennis; [[Royal Montreal Golf Club|Royal Montreal Golf]] and [[Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club|Royal St. Lawrence Yacht]] clubs.<ref>Who's who in Canada, Volume 46. International Press, 1958</ref> In {{nowrap|September 1962}}, Colonel Cape died after a short illness at the [[Royal Victoria Hospital, Montreal]].
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{authority control}}

{{about|Montenegrin online business magazine|Turkish weekly magazine|Ekonomist (Turkey)}} {{Distinguish|The Economist}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Ekonomist | image = EkonomistLogo.png | type = Online magazine | format = Magazine | foundation = 2014 | founder = Ljiljana Premović | owners = [http://be-positive.me BePositive] | political = | headquarters = [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]] | editor = Ljiljana Premović | price = | website = {{URL|http://ekonomist.me}} | circulation = | ISSN = | oclc = }} '''''Ekonomist''''' is a [[Montenegro|Montenegrin]] [[online magazine]], founded in 2014 in [[Podgorica]]. ''Ekonomist'''s primary focus is Montenegrin and world events, [[finances]], [[business]] and [[economy]]. It aims at promoting good [[business practice]] and developing [[entrepreneurial]] awareness, as an important aspect of [[economic growth]].<ref>[http://ekonomist.me/about/ About us]</ref> ''Ekonomist'' is also the only [[Fintech|''FinTech'']] portal in Montenegro, thus representing a platform for business and technology themes. In addition to national and world news, it features interviews, opinions, and career advice. Editor in chief is Ljiljana Premović.<ref>[http://ekonomist.me/impressum/ Impressum]</ref>
== Sources == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == *[http://ekonomist.me/ Official website]

revision.comment: light copyediting
/* Goals */USA is deprecated, per [[MOS:NOTUSA]], and correct [[MOS:OVERLINK|overlinking]] of common places using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Flanders District of Creativity''' or '''Flanders DC''' is a non-profit organization founded by the [[Flemish government]], on 7 May 2004, to make the Flemish economy more competitive through [[creativity]], [[entrepreneurship]], and further [[internationalization]].
==Goals== * Research: analysis of the role of creativity in the economic growth of a region, and how companies and organisations can get to more creativity and [[innovation]] (Flanders Knowledge center in collaboration with [[Vlerick Leuven Gent Management School]] and [[Antwerp Management School]]). * Creating awareness: stimulating [[policy maker]]s, the general public, companies and schools to tap into their creative potential. * Internationalization of creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship through collaboration with 13 other Districts of Creativity (DC). Besides [[Flanders]], these DCs are [[Baden-Württemberg]] (Germany), [[Catalunya]] (Spain), [[Central Denmark]] (Denmark), [[Karnataka]] (India), [[Lombardy]] (Italy), [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais]] (France), [[Oklahoma]] (US), [[Qingdao]] (China), [[Rhône-Alpes]] (France), [[Rio de Janeiro]] ([[Brasil]]), Scotland (United Kingdom), [[Shanghai]] (China), and [[Tampere]] ([[Finland]]).
==Projects/events== * Creativity World Forum (The DC's meet @ the CWF) * GPS brainstorming kit (idea generation tool) * Flanders DC Fellows (50 entrepreneurs, managers testify on [[creative entrepreneurship]] in schools) * De Bedenkers (TV Show in collaboration with Flanders DC) * SOS Idee (free first-aid service for people with an idea or invention) * The Future Summit (Event on trends) * ...
==See also== * [[Science and technology in Flanders]] * [[Institute for the promotion of Innovation by Science and Technology]] * [[Flanders Investment and Trade]] * [[Agoria]] * [[SIRRIS]], knowledge centre for the technology industry
==External links== * [http://www.flandersdc.be/ Flanders DC] (Flanders DC website and creativity portal) * [http://www.creativityworldforum.be/ Creativity World Forum] * [http://www.debedenkers.be/ De Bedenkers] * [http://www.thefuturesummit.be/ The Future Summit] * www.flandersdc.com is a hoax. The domain names FLANDERSDC.COM, FLANDERSDC.NET, FLANDERSDC.ORG and FLANDERS-DC.COM are the exclusive intellectual property of REDVERTISING SL. Redvertising has copied content and adapted the old Flanders DC logo from the old flandersdc.be in order to look a little bit like the original. These domains have nothing to do with Flanders District of Creativity, the organisation described in this article.
[[Category:Innovation organizations]] [[Category:Entrepreneurship organizations]] [[Category:Flanders]] [[Category:Government agencies of Belgium]] [[Category:Science and technology in Belgium]] [[Category:Research and development in Belgium]]

{{pp-sock|expiry=17:47, 19 April 2019|small=yes}} {{refimprove|date=April 2018}} {{coi|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Flora Call Disney | image = | birthname = Flora Call | caption = Flora with her husband, Elias | birth_date = {{birth date|1868|4|22|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Steuben, Ohio]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1938|11|26|1868|4|22|mf=y}} | death_place = [[North Hollywood, Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | death_cause = [[Asphyxiation]] caused by gas fumes | occupation = [[Housewife]] | relatives = See [[Disney family]] | nationality = American | spouse = {{marriage|[[Elias Disney]]
|1888}} | parents = Charles Call
Henrietta Gross | children = [[Walter Elias Disney]]
[[Disney family|Herbert Arthur Disney]]
[[Roy O. Disney|Roy Oliver Disney]]
[[Disney family|Raymond Arnold Disney]]
[[Disney family|Ruth Flora Disney]] }} '''Flora Call Disney''' (April 22, 1868{{spaced ndash}}November 26, 1938) was the mother of [[Walt Disney|Walt]] and [[Roy O. Disney|Roy Disney]]. ==Family== Call was born in [[Steuben, Ohio]], the daughter of Henrietta (née Gross; 1837–1910) and Charles Call (1823–1890), who were neighbors of Kepple Disney, father of [[Elias Disney]], her husband. She was of [[Germany|German]] and English descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.wargs.com/political/cheney.html|title=Ancestry of Dick Cheney (b. 1941)|work=wargs.com}} ==Death== Flora died in 1938 in an accident that plagued her son Walt with grief for the rest of his life.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lSJIngvkCsAC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA131#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=How to Be Like Walt: Capturing the Disney Magic Every Day of Your Life | publisher=HCI | author=Williams, Pat | year=2004 | pages=131}} After the success of their film ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'', in 1938, Walt and Roy presented their parents with a new home in [[North Hollywood]], near the Disney studios in [[Burbank, California]]. Less than a month after moving in, Flora complained to Walt and Roy of problems with the gas furnace in her new home. Studio repairmen were sent to the house, but the problem was not adequately fixed.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} Flora wrote a letter to her daughter Ruth describing the wonderful new home, but again complaining of the fumes from the furnace. A few days later, Flora died of [[asphyxiation]] caused by the fumes at age 70.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} She is entombed next to her husband in Glendale's [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Glendale|Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} *[[Roles of mothers in Disney media|Disney Mothers]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|8807}} *{{IMDb name|1089523|Flora Call Disney}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060106000050/http://www.teachersparadise.com/ency/en/wikipedia/f/fl/flora_call.html teacherparadise.com information] *[http://disney.go.com/disneyatoz/familymuseum/collection/biography/marceline/ Walt's Biography] *[http://www.answers.com/topic/flora-call-disney Flora Disney at Answers.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Disney, Flora Call}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in California]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]] [[Category:People from Huron County, Ohio]] [[Category:Burials at Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)]] [[Category:Disney family|Flora Call]]

{{lead too short|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Gigi Pritzker | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jean Pritzker | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|07|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = | nationality = United States | residence = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | education = B.A. [[Stanford University]] | alma_mater = | occupation = Film producer, Philanthropist | known_for = co-founder of [[Odd Lot Entertainment]] |networth = {{gain}} US$ 1.9 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] (March 2013)[https://www.forbes.com/profile/jean-gigi-pritzker/ Forbes: The World's Billionaires - Jean (Gigi) Pritzker] March 2013 | spouse = Michael Pucker | children = 3 | parents =[[Jay Pritzker]]
Marian "Cindy" Friend | website = | family = Nancy Pritzker (sister)
[[Thomas Pritzker]] (brother)
[[John Pritzker]] (brother)
[[Daniel Pritzker]] (brother) }} '''Jean "Gigi" Pritzker''' (born July 27, 1962) is an American billionaire, film producer, and philanthropist. She is a member of the [[Pritzker family]]. ==Early life and education== Pritzker was born to the wealthy [[American Jews|Jewish]] [[Pritzker family]] in [[Chicago, Illinois]], the daughter of Marian "Cindy" (née Friend) and [[Jay Pritzker]].[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1988/04/25/70462/index.htm CNN Money: "The Pritzker Unveiling a Private Family" By Ford S. Worthy] April 25, 1988 Her maternal grandfather was Prague-born jurist [[Hugo Friend]]. Her father diversified the Chicago-based family business, the [[Marmon Group]] - along with his brothers [[Robert Pritzker]] and [[Donald Pritzker]]. They created the [[Hyatt Hotel]] chain in 1957 and owned [[Braniff (1983–1990)|Braniff Airlines]] from 1983 until 1988, later divesting many assets.[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-04-19/business/ct-biz-0420-hyatt-filing-20110419_1_hyatt-founder-jay-pritzker-family-members-majority-stake Chicago Tribune: "Pritzker family could soon own less than half of Hyatt" By Julie Wernau] April 19, 2011 Pritzker graduated with a B.A. in [[anthropology]] from [[Stanford University]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/15/business/media/enders-game-is-a-bet-for-gigi-pritzkers-oddlot-entertainment.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 New York Times: "A Movie Mogul Rising" By MICHAEL CIEPLY] January 14, 2013 ==Career== After taking courses in documentary film making, she co-founded - along with her friend [[Deborah Del Prete]] - the [[Culver City, California]] based film production and financing company [[Odd Lot Entertainment]].[http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20130115/BLOGS03/130119890/gigi-pritzkers-firm-sees-star-rising-in-Hollywood Crain's Chicago Business: "Gigi Pritzker's firm sees star rising in Hollywood" by Shia Kapos] January 15, 2013 In 2010, Odd Lot produced the film ''[[Rabbit Hole (film)|Rabbit Hole]]'' starring [[Nicole Kidman]] and in 2011, produced the film ''[[Drive (2011 film)|Drive]]'' starring [[Ryan Gosling]].[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-12-18/business/ct-biz-1218-pritzkers-family-graphic--20111218_1_primary-residence-three-children-family-tree Chicago Tribune: "The Pritzker family tree" By Melissa Harris and Julie Wernau] December 18, 2011 In November 2013, Odd Lot released ''[[Ender's Game (film)|Ender's Game]]'' a film co-starring [[Harrison Ford]], and based on [[Orson Scott Card]]'s science fiction novel. Pritzker also develops and produces live stage productions - along with her partner Ted Rawlins - through their company Relevant Theatricals. Relevant Theatricals produced the play ''[[Million Dollar Quartet]]''. ==Personal life and philanthropy== Pritzker is president and a trustee of the Pritzker Pucker Family Foundation and the Chicago Children's Theatre. She is married to Michael Pucker[http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20121024/BLOGS03/121029919/gigi-michael-pucker-donate-sculpture-to-lurie-childrens-hospital Crain's Chicago Business: "Gigi, Michael Pucker donate sculpture to Lurie Children's Hospital" by Shia Kapos] October 24, 2012 and has three children.{{Cite web|last1=Harris |first1=Melissa |last2=Wernau |first2=Julie |authorlink= |title=The Pritzker family tree |publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=December 18, 2011 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-12-18/business/ct-biz-1218-pritzkers-family-graphic--20111218_1_primary-residence-three-children-family-tree |accessdate=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0698133}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pritzker, Jean}} [[Category:American people of Ukrainian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:Film producers from Illinois]] [[Category:American women film producers]] [[Category:Female billionaires]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Pritzker family|Gigi]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:People from Chicago]] [[Category:Philanthropists from Illinois]]
